Claudia Sheinbaum: Climate Champion or Fossil Fuel Friend?â 
â 
Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's newly elected president, comes into office with an impressive scientific background, having contributed to IPCC reports and served as an environmental minister. However, her long-standing alliance with the fossil fuel-friendly predecessor AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obrador raises concerns about her true commitment to climate action. â 
â 
As Mexico grapples with severe drought, heatwaves, and rising emissions, the stakes are high for Sheinbaum to translate her scientific expertise into tangible climate policies that address the country's pressing environmental challenges. The world watches closely to see if Sheinbaum will emerge as a true climate champion or remain entangled in the political landscape that favors fossil fuel interests.â

Recent Reads

I have not been posting much because shoulder and neck pain suck, but I have been immersing myself in stories.
 
Two of my most recent reads are Real Americans by @rrrrrrrachelkhong and Anita De Monte Laughs Last by @xochitltheg 

Both books have been pretty prominent here on booksta, so Iâ€™ll skip a synopsis. 

While both of these stories are very different, one thing that struck me is that they both feature immigrant (and first generation) women of color trying to make a mark in a rich, white patriarchal community. The way these books differ is in the stories and construction of the narratives.

Anita de Monte is a historical fiction novel that alternates between Anitaâ€™s storyline in the 60s and Raquelâ€™s storyline in the 90s (the nostalgia!). Gonzalez knows how to write heavy subjects so well, and this book definitely has some extremely well-written unlikeable characters (love that.) a warning that toxic relationships are featured in this story if thatâ€™s a trigger. But @xochitltheg I have so many questions about the bat character and now I have some post-life goals ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚. I found this one very thought provoking and Iâ€™m hoping Gonzalez is back at @miamibookfair this year to talk about this one.

Real Americans is a multi-viewpoint story, which is split between three characters from the same family. We start with Lily, mother of Nick and daughter to Mei. Three people who could not be more different. Each person tells their story from roughly the same age, and we see how generational trauma and trying to make life better for your children impact each characterâ€™s lives. I tore through this one and itâ€™s been lingering in my head ever since. 

Both of these have lots of good discussion points and Iâ€™d recommend them if youâ€™re looking for some thought provoking reads
